//TEST DESCRIPTIONS
This examination is done by a physician or qualified medical provider. The patient is evaluated for signs or symptoms of diseases, injury or illness. Providers will focus their examination on any pre existing medication conditions as well as new problems the patient may be experiencing.
This is a blood test is used to assess your overall health. It’s commonly performed during an exam by a health provider and checks for infection, decreased blood counts, and other diseases.
This blood test measures the amount of Valproic Acid in the blood stream. Valproic acid is an anticonvulsant medication used for patients who are prone to seizures.
Blood cultures are usually done in sets of 2. Blood is drawn from two different veins to check for infections in the blood. These samples are then sent to the laboratory for testing, eventually resulting in negative or positive blood cultures. These tests do not produce results in less than 24 hours.
A physician who diagnoses and treats the reproductive system of women. Additionally, they care for women throughout their pregnancy and during child birth.
Pelvic Exam Cultures are used to test for any type of bacteria that may be causing urinary tract infections or pain in the abdomen or vaginal area.
This is a blood test used to assess the overall health of your kidneys (creatinine and BUN), blood sugar levels (glucose), as well as electrolytes in your body such as potassium (K), Sodium (Na), and Calcium (Ca).
An antibiotic is a medication that destroys bacteria in the body. This medication is used to fight off small infections such as skin infections as well as large infections such as urinary infections or pneumonia.
OBGYN is short for doctors who are specialists in obstetrics and gynecology. These doctors treat and care for women\'s reproductive systems, pregnancies and childbirth.
This blood test provides information on how fast the blood is clotting. Patients taking blood thinners monitor their INR values with their physicians assistance to keep the values within a specified range.
Sutures are also known as stitches. These are used to repair cuts which will not heal unless the skin is pulled together for an extended time period.
This blood test helps to determine if a patient has heart failure. It is most commonly used to monitor the degree of heart failure with patients who have CHF (congestive heart failure disease).
These are a series of tests that your healthcare provider will perform to assess a patient\'s eyes. A visual acuity test includes reading progressively small letters or numbers from a pre defined distance. The provider may also shine light in the eye to look for abnormalities.
This blood test determines the level of acetaminophen in the blood stream. Acetaminophen is also known as tylenol and is found in a variety of other pain medications.
This blood tests determines the level of aspirin in the blood. Aspirin is used for pain relief but also can become dangerous if high levels exist in the body.
The rapid strep test involved taking a swab sample of from the back of the throat using a q-tip shaped swab. It is used to test for group A streptococci which is another name for the more commonly used Strep Throat.
Eye drops are small drops of liquid medicine that are put into the eye for multiple different reasons including pain control or to treat infections or damage to the eye.
This blood test is routinely performed as part of your physical exam by your physician in evaluating overall health. It includes 10+ tests that asses your body’s electrolyte balance as well as test for kidney disease, liver disease and diabetes.
This blood test measures an enzyme produced by your pancreas which is called lipase. Elevated levels of lipase suggest pancreatitis or inflammation of your pancreas. Signs and symptoms of pancreatitis may include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting and fever.
This blood test is performed to evaluate for a disease process inside your body. Healthcare providers may use this to test for inflammation, pain, swelling or even arthritis. It is not specific to a certain disease process, it only tells the healthcare provider if you may have a an active disease process.
This blood test is used to check the body for possible blood clots. D-Dimer is released by the body when a blood clot is formed. If a DVT (deep vein thrombosis) or a PE (pulmonary embolism) is suspected, the physician may order a D-Dimer test.
This blood test checks for enzymes released from the heart when damage may have been done to the heart from a disease process or during a heart attack. Chest pain, abnormal EKG, or chronic/acute heart failure are possible indications for a troponin blood test.
This consultation is when the emergency room doctor speaks with the physician who takes care of patients on the inpatient floors of the hospital. It\'s commonly done when a patient is going to be admitted to the hospital.
Patients are connected to a vital sign monitoring machine which monitors heart rate and rhythm (HR), oxygen levels in the blood (SP02), respiratory rate (RR) and blood pressure (BP).
This test is used to evaluate the blood sugar level in the blood. A lancet is used to prick the finger and a small drop of blood is tested.
This blood test is used to diagnose or manage pancreatitis, appendicitis, eating disorders or infections. Elevated amylase levels are commonly associated with acute pancreatitis, swelling in your abdomen, ulcers, intestine blockages, sudden gallbladder swelling, alcohol use and other acute problems.
GI doctors treat disorders of the gastrointestinal tract which includes primarily the stomach, intestines and colon.
This test is a collection of your stool. It is used to test for sources of digestive tract infections. Symptoms which may require stool cultures include diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, or blood in stool.
This blood test checks the overall health of the liver. The liver is a large organ that turns food into nutrients and energy. Dark urine, abdominal pain, fatigue, yellow skin color, or dark colored stools are all possible indications for this blood test.
This blood test is used to test if a woman is pregnant by testing the level of HCG hormone in the bloodstream. Elevated levels of HCG increase in the first three months of pregnancy. It also may be ordered if vaginal bleeding or cramping is present. This test may also be done in a series to determine changes in the level of HCG in the bloodstream.
This is a blood test which is used to diagnose thyroid problems. The thyroid is located near your throat and is responsible for hormones affect weight, moods, energy levels, insomnia, generalized weakness and fatigue as well as other symptoms. Hyperthyroidism as well as hypothyroidism each have many signs and symptoms.
This blood test measures the level of uric acid in your bloodstream. Uric acid increases when your kidneys can not properly rid it from your body through urinating. Most commonly excessive uric acid is seen when patients have increasing pain in their joints or kidney stones. In addition, symptoms of gout may be present, which includes joint swelling and redness.
This is a blood test most commonly used to ensure patients requiring a blood transfusion or possible blood transfusion receive the blood type that matches their own. It also tests for antibodies in the blood that are present to ensure no transfusion reaction occurs during the transfusion process.
This test is a collection of a patient\'s urine which is used to diagnose infections, kidney problems, diabetes and/or liver disease. This test is part of a regular health examination but more specifically with patients experiencing abdominal pain, burning while urinating or blood in the urine.
This is a blood test that is taken from either the vein or the artery usually in the arm or wrist. It is used to evaluate how well a patient’s lungs are functioning. Having excessive acid (acidosis) or base (alkalosis) can be extremely dangerous to a patient’s health.
These tests are commonly done when a person has difficulty breathing, has increasing fatigue, is disoriented, or has had excessive smoke inhalation.
An EKG creates a wave form-like picture of the electrical activity of the heart as it beats. 12 stickers are applied to the patient\'s chest, legs and arms and connected to wires on the EKG machine. The image will be evaluated by the health providers for signs of decreased oxygen flow, abnormal heart rhythms, or electrolyte imbalances such as potassium. These tests are commonly performed in the emergency department or family doctor office.
Definition for IV Placement: A small catheter will be inserted into the vein, usually in the arm. There is a small needle that helps the catheter into the skin but then needle is then removed, leaving only a small plastic catheter in the vein for infusions of medicine, IV fluid, or blood.
This therapy is often referred to as an “IV drip”. During this process, liquid is infused into the vein through an IV catheter. This therapy can be used to correct electrolyte imbalances, rehydrate, give medications, or transfuse blood.
IV fluid is given through a catheter in the vein to patients who need hydration. In very mild cases of dehydration, patients can drink fluid to rehydrate, but in more severe cases, patients will receive fluid through an IV catheter.
This test involves inserting a Q-tip shaped swab through your nose and into the cavity behind your nose called the nasopharynx. The swab is rotated several times in the nasopharynx to collect a proper sample where the influenza is virus is detectable. This test does not hurt and will not injury you, but it is slightly uncomfortable when the swab is inserted.
This test is a measurement of how much oxygen and carbon dioxide are in the blood stream. This blood is taken using a needle from the artery or a vein.
This test is performed to evaluate the sugar level in a the blood. After pricking the finger, a small drop of blood is tested using an blood glucose level machine. This test may be performed to asses causes of blurred vision, increased urination, weight loss, increased thirst, confusion, or other diabetes. The test results are usually available in less than 15 seconds.
During this procedure, a tube is inserted through the penis or urethra into the bladder. This is commonly used when a patient is having difficulty urinating, has blood in their urine, is unaware when they are urinating, or when it’s important to monitor how much urine the body is producing. There is a short period of discomfort when the catheter is inserted. In some cases the catheter is left in the bladder for an extended time and in other instances, the catheter is placed to obtain urine and then immediately removed.
During this examination, a healthcare provider will commonly insert a speculum into the vagina and examine the vulva (external genital), cervix (opening from vagina to uterus), uterus (the womb), fallopian tubes (tubes that carry eggs to the uterus), bladder (holds urine), and the rectum (area that connects the colon to the anus).
Breathing treatments given to patients who are experiencing difficulty breathing. This medicine is in liquid form but turned into a mist which is inhaled into the lungs. These treatments are commonly used for patients with asthma or other breathing conditions.
This is a device that is used to measure the amount of air that flows out of a person’s lungs when they breathe. It is most commonly used to assess the status of a patient with asthma. Low readings compared to a patient’s normal reading may mean the lungs are not performing as they should be.
If a chemical gets into a patients eye, commonly the eye is irrigated with a sterile water solution. This can be done over a sink using an emergency eye wash system or using a Morgan Lens which covers the cornea and allows for continuous flow of solution to give relief from chemical or thermal burns as well as foreign materials that are not embedded in the eye.
There are a variety of pain medications that are given to patients. Each medication is given by a healthcare provider with direction of a medical doctor. It is important to ask the healthcare provider side effects of these medications as well as make them aware of any allergies you may have to these pain medications.
These medications are used to treat nausea and vomiting. They are commonly used in the emergency department or after surgery. They can be given orally or be given through a patient’s IV catheter in their vein.
Blood products such a red blood cells or fresh frozen plasma are given during sudden blood loss from trauma, surgery, or in patients who have chronic low blood counts (anemia). Prior to receiving blood through the IV catheter, a patient’s blood type will be identified to ensure a blood transfusion reaction does not occur. Your physician will inform you of the risks and benefits of receiving blood transfusions.
Tetanus is a potentially fatal disease in the central nervous system. The bacteria can enter into the body through a cut in the skin. It can take anywhere from 3-21 days to have symptoms of tetanus which include jaw stiffness (lockjaw), fast heart rate, sweating, stiffness in facial muscles, difficult swallowing and others. Children and adults are given tetanus vaccines through intramuscular shots as well as booster shots. Consult with your physician to get the most up to date information on your tetanus vaccination status.
This type of imaging uses small levels of radiation to show images of organs, bones, and other parts of the body to diagnose infections such as pneumonia, fractures, intestinal blockages, excessive fluid around the heart, and many other medical problems. X-rays are commonly used in emergency departments as well as part of a physical exams.
This scan produces imagines of the body including organs, muscles, fat and bones. It is a much more detailed picture than an x-ray and is used frequently for headaches, abdominal pain or chest pain.
This test is commonly used to assess function the kidneys, arteries, breasts or the heart. It can also be used to evaluate the fetus during pregnancy. This type of medical imaging is usually painless.
This imaging uses magnet, radio waves and a computer to create the most detailed images of the body’s organs, bones, fat and tissue. During this test, the patient lays flat on a table and is moved into a tube shaped scanner. An MRI is used to further evaluate conditions in the body while not emitting any radiation to the patient.
This is a noninvasive procedure that evaluates the function of the heart and structures around the heart. Similar to an ultrasound, a probe is put up against the chest and picture is created in real time of the heart on the computer screen. This painless procedure is used to diagnose diseases such as congenital heart diseases and defects, cardiomyopathy, congestive heart failure, aneurysms as well as infections around the heart such as pericarditis.
This test is done by walking on a treadmill or riding a stationary bike while being evaluated by a healthcare professional. Your heart rate, blood pressure and breathing is monitored. This test is used if a doctor believes you may have adequate blood flow to your heart, abnormal heart rhythms, or lack of oxygen reaching your heart.
This supplemental oxygen is used to increase levels of oxygen in the body. It can be administered through non rebreather (mask) or a nasal cannula (tubing that directs oxygen in the nose). This supplemental air is 100% oxygen while the air we breathe all around us is 21% oxygen.
This blood test indicates inflammation inside the body. If there is inflammation inside the body, the level of this test will rise.
This blood test is used to evaluate patients with undiagnosed or known liver disease that are experiencing confusion or have become severely ill.
This blood test is used to evaluate signs of septic shock, heart attack, congestive heart failure, kidney failure or trauma. This test does not specifically indicate failure of a specific organ, but it does indicate the severity of a disease or condition.
Swallow Screen is an evaluation that assesses if it is safe to allow a patient to swallow food, water, or medication. If a patient has difficulty completing the swallow screen, generally the patient will not be allowed to eat or drink (NPO). These are done mainly on patients who exhibit signs or symptoms of having had or recently had a stroke.
A doctor that treats diseases and conditions in a surgical or non surgical means effecting the brain, spinal cord, nerves and nervous system.
Neurologists are doctors who are trained in treating disorders and diseases of the brain and nervous system, nerves, muscles and spinal cord.
Urologists are doctors who specialize in the treatment and care of the female and male urinary tract as well as the male reproductive organs.
Social workers are professionals who help to improve the overall care as well as life of patients within the hospital. They can be beneficial in helping with finding appropriate care after leaving the hospital, providing resources helping with addiction, helping to organize family care and many other aspects of patient care.
A cardiologist is a doctor who has been trained to treat and care for problems with the heart, arteries and veins.
Surgeons are doctors who perform invasive procedures to help treat or repair diseases or injuries inside the body.
Drawn at 3 hour or 6 hour intervals, this blood test is a second test which checks for an increase in protein released from the heart, possibly from a heart attack or other heart condition.
Complete Blood Count Basic Metabolic Panel or Electrolyte Panel Standardized Prothrombin time Comprehensive Metabolic Panel Serum lipase Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate, Sed Rate Cardiac Troponin Fibrin Degradation Fragment stool sample hepatic function test, liver function test serum HCG thryoid stimulating hormone serum uric acid blood typing Urine Screening arterial blood gas, venous blood gas electrocardiogram intravenous catheter intravenous therapy/hydration influenza test Strep Throat Test blood sugar level foley catheter, in/out cath Breathing Treatment Narcotic, non-narcotic, NSAIDS, central analgesics, topical anesthetics Antiemetics RBC & FFP Tetanus Computed Tomography abdominal ultrasound, fetal ultrasound, trans-vaginal ultrasound Magnetic Resonance Imaging Echocardiogram Treadmill Test O2 Obstetrics and Gynecology C-reactive protein Lactate
